answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Dorian, 
I have been able to find some resources that should help answer your question. The majority of documents I found support the idea of a centralized call center. 
To begin, there was a question similar to yours asked last March. The individual was seeking to get feedback on how local governments had set up their call center service. There were a lot of positive responses to the 311 system, as well as some helpful links.
http://bit.ly/j5qqeT
Among the links provided in the answers, was the link to ICMA’s study of 311 technology. The website provides additional links to specific case studies and other documents that should be useful in seeing how these systems were implemented, as well as their results:
http://bit.ly/k34wAk
A good case study that the site provides is from Lynwood, California. The city created a central customer service position to avoid citizens with complaints going through multiple departments to find the right person to help them. They also implemented a seven digit number for handling citizen requests so citizens do not have to know which department was the right one to take care of their request before calling:
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/7130 
Finally, ICMA conducted a survey to see what types of telephone response systems local governments were using across the country. The results can be found at:
http://bit.ly/ksPF3E
I hope these help!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

author: Dorian Kachur
text:
Airdrie is looking for research or information on whether it is better to have callers seeking municipal services call a central point of contact to be either answered or transferred to the correct department, or to publish many individual departmental direct lines, and let customers self-select.  
Our goal is to limit the number of times that a customer is transferred between departments, the risk being that a misdirected self-selected call may result in further misdirection by a department incorrectly redirecting it, versus a well-trained and informed call centre operator fielding the bulk of the calls and routing them with more certainty.  
Thanks!
title: Best practices for Fielding Telephone Enquiries
